column17: I think it would be beneficial to describe how one would profile ActivityDefinition. Also, I am not clear about how dynamicValues are defined given the example provided. The category is 'drug' but the dynamicValue references what seems to be a path from MedicationOrder. How does one know that the context of the ActivityDefinition in this case is a medication order apart from looking at the id? It seems that ActivityDefinition needs to be vetted further to ensure it can meet requirements.

Somewhere in the Clinical reasoning documentation, we should formally explain dynamicValue and offer a number of illustrative and comprehensive examples on its use.

The devil for order sets lies in the details. From the example, it is not clear how one represents an orderable item, its details, and its constraints and behavior. I suggest that we have a few example here or elsewhere that shows precisely how an orderable catalog item is associated with a specific detail model which can have default and precheck settings and value set constraints that are based on the orderable catalog item associated with the details (codeset scoping for, say, frequency, route of administration, etc... of a strength med vs a volume med for instance).
column18: Clarify/expand on how to use Clinical Reasoning module for Order Sets

column15: To reduce the size of returned results and ensure efficient searching and retrieval, the Bundle returned SHOULD consist only of resources of the requested type. Dependencies of the resources returned SHOULD NOT be included.
column17: In order to align with the Order Catalog Service Functional Model, a search for knowledge artifacts should support an option to return a 'fully hydrated' self-contained payload as a bundle as an option. It should also support a result set containing only selected metadata for the artifact. For instance, one may wish to get back a list of order set summaries only. One may also wish to get a list of order sets with all referenced content included for export.
column18: Support different levels of output for artifact distribution

column15: Although the MeasureReport is conceptually an Observation, there is enough specific information required to support the quality reporting use case to warrant a separate resource.
column17: In the grander scheme of things, everything that is a name-value pair is an 'observation'. Thus, how does one know whether to create a new resource or define a profile on observation? My take is that in cases where significant extensions and constraints would be required, a new resource is probably warranted. Moreover, a MeasureReport probably deserves a resource of its own given its importance and the fact that its overlap with Observation, beyond the fact that both have a value, is not great. Lastly, it seems that a MeasureReport is a document rather than a clinical statement.
column18: Clarify relationship between MeasureReport and Observation

column17: A section mentioning the security concerns about using CQL expressions within FHIR Resources may be useful.
column18: A section mentioning the security concerns about using CQL expressions within FHIR Resources may be useful.

column17: NIOSH recommends the inclusion of Occupational Data for Health (ODH) in the FHIR standard. Currently, the ODH HL7 CDA template is in ballot reconciliation through the Structured Documents Work Group. NIOSH is intent on incorporating and aligning ODH in all HL7 standards. A Project Scope Statement (PSS) to format ODH in V2 and FHIR standards is with the Executive Board and Technical Steering Committee (TSC) to identify the appropriate sponsor Work Group. Use cases to support ODH can be provided during ballot reconciliation.
Would be nice to be able to separate out the data from the CDS (e.g. point to an observation profile to be used for capturing data).  Is this possible now (or can be added if not)?
Would be nice to separate out decision rules from the code (e.g. load in CDS rules via reference).  Is this possible now (or can be added if not)?
Should probably be section 14.0.1.2

The definition of ActivityDefinition, "A… description of some activity to be performed" is very similar to the definition of Task: "describes an activity that can be performed".  Realizing that Task is a new resource, I think it's incumbant on you to explain in your definition why ActivityDefinition is different than Task, and probably say when you use one versus the other.
column18: Clarify relationship between ActivityDefinition and Task

The resource isn't actually described until the 3rd paragraph.

column15: As with other knowledge artifacts, logic is included by referencing a Library resource. Although the base resource allows for the measure to reference any number of libraries, for simplicity of managing sharing, this implementation guide requires that a measure reference only one Library, the primary measure library, and that this library contain all the named expressions required to define the measure structure.

column15: This Implementation Guide (IG) specifies how the Clinical Quality Language (CQL) is used in conjunction with the Quality Improvement Core (QICore)  FHIR profiles to define and invoke clinical quality measures.

column15: QRDA documents come in three flavors: Category I for individual patient reports, Category II for patient list reports, and Category III for population reports.

column15: An order set is a pre-defined and approved group of orders related to a particular clinical condition (e.g., hypertension treatment and monitoring) or stage of care (e.g., hospital admission to Coronary Care Unit).
column16: An order set is a pre-defined and approved group of orders related to a particular clinical condition (e.g., hypertension treatment and monitoring) or a particular period of time.
column17: Order sets are not limited to clinical conditions and stage of care.  a particular period of time-- (pediatrics, adult,  screenings for men > 50 or for women > 40; and admission order sets)
column18: Broadening the definition of order sets.

column15: This encoding may be as simple as controlling whether or not a particular section of an order set appears based on the specific conditions that are present for the patient in content in a CPOE system, or it may be as complex as representing the care pathway for patients with multiple conditions.
column16: This encoding may be as simple as controlling whether or not a particular section of an order set appears based on the conditions that a patient has, or it may be as complex as representing the care pathway for a patient with multiple conditions.
column17: Grammar suggestion.

column15: Sharing - The ability to represent clinical knowledge artifacts such as decision support rules, order sets, protocols, and quality measures, and to do so in a way that enables those artifacts to be shared across organizations and institutions.
column16: Sharing - The ability to represent clinical knowledge artifacts such as decision support rules, order sets, protocols, and quality measures, and to do so in a way that enables those artifacts to be shared across organizations.
column17: Grammar suggestion.

column15:
These components are:
    Expression Logic - The ability to represent expression logic using languages such as FluentPath and Clinical Quality Language (CQL).
    Definitional Resources - The ability to describe definitional resources, or template resources that are not defined on any specific patient, but are used to define the actions to be performed as part of a clinical knowledge artifact such as an order set or decision support rule.
    Knowledge Artifacts - The ability to represent clinical knowledge artifacts such as decision support rules and clinical quality measures.
column16:
These components are:
    Expression Logic - the representation of logic using languages such as FluentPath and Clinical Quality Language (CQL).
    Definitional Resources - template resources that are not defined on any specific patient, but are used to define the actions to be performed as part of a clinical knowledge artifact such as an order set or decision support rule.
    Knowledge Artifacts - representation of clinical knowledge such as decision support rules and clinical quality measures.
column17: Grammar suggestion.

column15: If you're interested in the background and development of the Clinical Quality Framework, this topic covers where it came from and why it exists.
column16: If you are interested in the background and development of the FHIR Clinical Reasoning module, this topic covers where it came from and why it exists.
column17: Grammar suggestion.

column15: The CQF Implementation Guide
column16: The FHIR Clinical Reasoning module
column17: Grammar suggestion.

column15:
The strategy employed has been to break the conceptual content of knowledge artifacts into three core components, to define common standards for these core components, and to re-use these common standards for both clinical decision support and clinical quality measurement:
    Metadata - Descriptive information about the artifact and its content
    Clinical Information - The representation used to represent clinical information about the patient or population of concern within a given artifact
    Logic - The representation used to convey the logic involved in the artifact
column16:
The strategy employed has been to break the conceptual content of knowledge artifacts into three core components, to define common standards for these core components, and to re-use these common standards for both clinical decision support and clinical quality measurement:
    Metadata - Descriptive information about the artifact and its content
    Clinical Information - Information about a patient or population of concern within a given artifact
    Logic - The clinical reasoning involved in an artifact
column17: Grammar suggestion.

column15: If the containing resource has a library element (such as ActivityDefinition and PlanDefinition), and only specifies a single library, the expression is evaluated as though it is in scope in that library. However, if the resource references multiple libraries, the referenced expression must be qualified with the name of the library in order to ensure unambiguous resolution.
column17: Please provide an example.

column15: For resources that do not have a library element, the library extension can be used to reference a library from any resource.
column17: Please clarify.  For example, if you define an order set that refers to an expression, and the order set doesn't have a library, could the library really be anywhere?  Or does it need to be in the same scope somehow?  This is unclear how it would actually work, and what the restrictions are for what other resources can contain the relevant library.
column18: Clarify relationship between order set and library

column15: For simplicity, resources that use logic libraries SHOULD reference at most one library to avoid the need to qualify expression references.
column17: I'm not sure about this.  What if there are common libraries we want to re-use, e.g., for common expressions for time operations, etc.?  I can see where we would want to create something like a "CommonFunctions" library that we include in most knowledge artifacts.  This guidance would seem to say that such an approach should not be used, which I'm not sure is the right guidance to give.
column18: Clarify reason for single library requirement

column17: This section on Evaluation Context makes sense at a generic level, but I think that examples and elaboration would be useful.  E.g.: - what is meant by an implicit Context?  How is that defined?  What are examples of when expressions are contained within a resource?  What about examples of when expressions are not contained within a resource?

column15: No name element - Because patient-dependent information is accessed in CQL through the use of a retrieve expression, there is no need to specify a name in order to access the information.
column16: No name element - Because there is no need for a name to inference on the data, there is no need to specify a name for the data required.
column17: Suggest modifying the text to cover the evaluate operation, which does not require the use of CQL.

column15: Code and date filters - The CQL retrieve also allows for data accessed to be filtered by membership in a specific valueset, as well as by date range. The DataRequirement type represents these filters via the codeFilter and dateFilter elements.
column16: Code and date filters - the data required can be filtered by membership in a specific valueset, as well as by date range. The DataRequirement type represents these filters via the codeFilter and dateFilter elements.
column17: Suggest modifying the text to cover the evaluate operation, which does not require the use of CQL.

column15: FluentPath is a lightweight path-based navigation language intended to provide simple but flexible access to graph-structured data. It is defined as a general purpose specification available here .

column15: And further, it is often the case that the values for the elements of resources to be created cannot be specified exactly as part of the definition, but be specified using a formula that allows for the calculation to be based on patient- or context-specific information.
column16: Further, it is often the case that the values for the elements of resources to be created cannot be specified exactly as part of the definition, but must be specified using a formula that allows for the calculation to be based on patient- or context-specific information.

column15: For medication activities, the ActivityDefinition resource has some basic elements such as the product and quantity, but there is not enough information to describe more complex dosing scenarios. In those cases, the dynamicValue expression elements can be used to describe the values for elements that are present on the target resource, but not in the definitional resource

column16: In addition, artifacts may have logical identifiers based on the content or behavior they provide, such as the CMS or NQF identifiers for measure content.

column15: Additional documentation can be provided using the relatedResource element to link to detailed information, supporting evidence, and to additional required artifacts as appropriate.

column15: [Status mapping that combines status and experimental flag]
column16:
[Status mapping that separates status and experimental flag]. 
E.g.: Exp | draft -> Draft, InTest -> DRAFT, DEFINED
Exp | active -> InTest -> DEFINED
Exp | inactive -> inactive -> REJECTED
Non-Exp | draft -> Draft, InTest -> DRAFT, DEFINED
Non-Exp | active -> Active-> APPROVED, PROMOTED
Non-Exp | inactive -> Inactive -> REJECTED, RETIRED
column17: Should also probably clarify the relationship between an experimental artifact and a non-experimental artifact in draft state.  E.g., is it reasonable to start an artifact in experimental stage, do draft, then active through testing, then transition that to non-experimental and active because it's already been tested?  Or should it be that anything that is anticipated to see production use following testing be flagged non-experimental to begin with?

column15: Order sets are used within electronic health record systems as a checklist for physicians when treating a patient with a specific condition.

column15: [Protocol] A pre-defined procedural method written to standardize a set of activities. Protocols can be used within laboratory settings to standardize handling of specimens or the steps involved in a specific test, to describe the methodology for effective treatment of a particular condition, or the steps to be taken in a particular research trial.
column16: [Protocol] A pre-defined procedural method for standardizing a set of activities. As examples, protocols can be used within laboratory settings to standardize handling of specimens for specific tests; standardize the treatment steps for a particular condition; or standardize the steps to be taken in a particular research trial.
column17: Original sentence structure did not make clear that other types of protocols can exist.  Also applies to G4.6, and potentially other places where the description is used.

column15: [Library] A general purpose container for clinical knowledge defined in non-FHIR structures. For example, a sharable package of clinical logic expressed in Clinical Quality Language.

column15: The use of FHIR operations as the protocol for defining artifact evaluation requests and responses. In particular, the ability to bundle multiple requests into a single operation, as well as the use of a generic FHIR operation for any service module evaluation, versus defining an evaluation specific to a given knowledge artifact.
column17: I think the rule of thumb should be that we should perhaps have at most dozens or hundreds of operations to cover 90-95% of CDS use cases, vs. thousands or tens of thousands.  This would imply that the re-use of operational structures should happen to at least some extent.  Also, the ability to minimize processing time, such as through bundling, is critically important and must be a priority for the specification to support.  In any case, we should make sure the proposed way forward is feasible for scalable, high-performance use.

column15:
DataRequirement.mustSupport
Definition 

Indicates that specific elements of the type are referenced by the knowledge module and must be supported by the consumer in order to obtain an effective evaluation. This does not mean that a value is required for this element, only that the consuming system must understand the element and be able to provide values for it if they are available.

column18: Recommend clarifying how to represent required nested attributes.

E.g., how do you say -- provide me observations whose observationDateTime is in the past year, OR whose observationDatePeriod is in teh past year?  Or do we anticipate such a case would not occur?

column15: The MeasureType value set contains 2 concepts- process and outcome.
column16: Add conecepts for "structure"  "patient reported outcome," and "composite" as defined by NQF and used in the CMS measure endorsement process (CMS MMS Blueprint).
column17: While to date, most eCQMs are process or outcome measures, CQL and FHIR could be used to define structure measures, specifically those that evaluate health IT. Additionally, the measurement field tends to differentiate between Outcome measures, which are clinical outcomes, and Patient Reported Outcome measures, which include measures of patient engagement and experience. Finally, a "Composite" measure is a combination of two or more individual measures that results in a single score. There are existing Composite eCQMS.  Adding these concepts will provide measure developers with a more concise set of descriptors.
column18: Add the concepts "Structure", "Patient Reported Outcome", and "Composite" to the MeasureType value set.

column15: G.7.1.3.1 "The data criteria for the primary library defines the patient data of interest…"
column16: "The data criteria for the primary library defines the data of interest…"
column17: Measures  include data other than patient data, including administrative and facility data
column18: Remove the context of "patient" to references to measure data, as not all data used in measurement is patient data.

column16: Add concept for "Measure Observation"
column17: Currently, continuous variable measures contains "Measure Observation" which is not part of this FHIR value set.  If "Measure Observation" and "Measure Score" are considered the same, then this needs to be clarified within the specification.  If not, then "Measure Observation" needs to be added.  See the eCQM CMS111 (ED-2) for an example.
column18: Either add or clarify the concept "Measure Observation".

column17: Revise table in G.7.1.2.1: Specifiying Population Criteria, to include column for "Measure Observation."
column18: Modify section G.7.1.2.1  to include the population criteria type "Measure Observation".

column15: G.7.1.2.3. "Measure observations are not population criteria in that they do not determine whether or not a patient is to be counted in a measure."
column17: This differentiation is unecessarily complex. Measure observations define computations to be performed on measure populations. They are not a unique population, but they do include population 'criteria.' I have not seen the definition provided in past and question its value. Also question where measure observations would be specified, if not in the population criteria as they are currently.
column18: Modify section G.7.1.2.3 discussion concerning Measure Observations.

column17: Given the description of the OperationDefinition resource in section G.7.2.1, is it necessary to retain a population value of "measure score?" Also, Measure score implies that the score is a unique population, but a score is the result of the operation against the defined population criteria.  OR is "Measure Score" the same as "Measure Observation" in HQMF?

The structure and UML provided in 14.7.3 looks like the patient-level MeasureReport is framed around the measure instead of the patient.  QRDA-I reports are framed around the patient such that the data for all measures for which a patient qualifies is submitted in one file. How is it expected that MeasureReports will be submitted when a patient falls into multiple measures (e.g., CMS111, CMS91, etc?)?  Will it be based on each measure, rather than as a document containing all data for a single patient?
Secondary data receivers frequently need all of the discrete data for a patient in order to perform other operations beyond those specified in the measure, such as 'risk adjustment', 'denovo measure development', and 'data quality/interoperability analysis'.  Data receivers that are not able to receive actual patient identifiers (e.g., patient's medicare/medicaid numbers) will be unable to recombine a patient's data for this analysis.
column18: Review and provide more information concerning the patient-level Measure Report structure.

column15: G.7.3.2. Reporting Individual Data-"…the result SHOULD include a reference to a Bundle containing the patient-specific resources that were used to calculate the result."
column16: …the result SHALL include a reference to a Bundle containing the patient-specific resources that were used to calculate the result.
column17: Patient-level MeasureReports must include patient-specific resources, and the resource values.  The patient-level data is essential in evaluating the validity and reliability of measures, and is necessary in order to provide meaningful reports back to data senders regarding missing data, common responses, and other criterion-level analyses.
column18: Patient-level MeasureReports must include patient-specific resources, and the resource values.

column15: G.7.3.3.2 "See the MeasureReport examples for a detailed illustration of how the data elements involved in the calculation of the measurea re commuicated through the evaluatedResources element
column17: There do not appear to be human-readable narrative examples of measure reports, only XML and JSON. As a measure developer with limited technical experience, the XML and JSON representations are not sufficient for me to comment on the measure report format. Suggest adding  narrative examples, as they would be most helpful in understanding what exactly data and in what format the MeasureReport returns, and will be needed in order for developers to provide meaningful comment.
column18: Provide a human-readable narrative for measure reports to assist in review and education.

column15: G.4.1.2.1 "General documentation elements, including description, purpose, and usage, provide immediately available documentatino for the use of the artifact as part of the artifact"
column16: Uncertain the intent, but suggest rephrasing bolded text
column17: Please see existing wording exerpt- unclear what is intended by the "use of the artifact as part of the artifact"

Unable to evaluate examples of resource libararies as Section 14.3.5 Resource Library-Examples- Content links to "CQL Source" yield HTTP Error 404, as do the narratives provided in the Example list.   Michelle mayhave time to review these as part of ballot reconcilliation if provided a human-readable example.
column18: Correct links and provide to measure developer to review as part of ballot reconcilliation.

column17: The Clinical Decision Support (services) section needs additional examples with additional detail.  There are too few examples for an implementer to use this guide effectively in its current form.  Suggestion to provide end-to-end examples for atleast three use cases: for example- guidance for an imaging order; guidance for a medication order; and calculating BMI when opening the chart.  For each use case, we would like to see fully worked out examples, including all or almost all data elements in DecisionSupportServiceModule, $evaluate request, and GuidanceResponse, and covering synchronous, asynchronous, conversational and bundling flows.

GuidanceResponse.OutputParam.Result vs GuidanceResponse.Action: while providing mutliple options to deliver CDS output back to EMRis helpful. Having guidance on when to use which option will be helpful?
column18: Guidance on when to use different types of output for CDS evaluations
